title: The Childcare Handbook: Needs, Programs & Possibilities
abstract: This document explains the Comprehensive Child Development Act of 1971, which was vetoed by President Richard Nixon. Part I, "Who Needs Child Care," documents a range of pressing social and economic forces and everyday personal crises that contribute to a growing majority of families' being likely to need child care services at some point to help them stay intact. Part II, "Program Profiles," highlights several model child care programs such as the After School Day Care Association, Inc. in Madison, Wisconsin; the A.P. Beutel II Day Care Center in Freeport, TX; and the Child Care Resource and Referral, Inc. in Rochester, Minnesota. Part III draws further upon the accumulated experience of workshop participants to spell out what advocates can do in both immediate and the longer range to protect and expand existing local and national child care programs that are working.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: State Developments in Child Care, Early Education, and School-Age Care 2000
abstract: This report provides highlights and updates regarding state actions on child care, early education, and school-age care issues during 2002. It is intended to serve as a supplement to State Developments in Child Care, Early Education, and School-Age Care 2001; State Developments in Child Care and Early Education 1999; State Child Care and Early Education Developments; Highlights and Updates for 1998; and State Developments in Child Care and Early Education 1997.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: State Developments in Child Care and Early Education
abstract: This report includes information on the broad range child care and early education issues that states addressed in 1997, including State Decisions Regarding Child Care Funding, Child Care Assistance and "Guarantees" of Assistance, Changes in Child Care Subsidy Policies, Actions Related to Quality and Supply, Changes in Child Care Administration and Efforts to Create Unified Policies, Head Start and Prekindergarten Iniatives, and Other Ideas and Developments. This information was collected through phone interviews with experts in each state.
subject_topic_LCSH2: Federal aid to day care centers
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: State Child Care and Early Education Developments: Highlights and Updates for 1998
abstract: This report is one of a series of reports by CDF concerning state policies and practices in child care and education. The report provides highlights and updates regarding state actions on child care and early education issues during 1998. The report is intended to serve as a supplement and companion to the more comprehensive information presented in State Developments in Child Care and Early Education 1997. The information in the report was collected through written surveys and phone interviews with advocates in each state. The final draft was reviewed for verification by advocates and state child care administrators in each state.
subject_topic_LCSH: Federal aid to day care centers
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: The Health Insurance Crisis for America's Children
abstract: The information presented in this report documents research conducted over a decade demonstrating the poor state of America's maternal and child health. The report emphasizes that America's families desperately need health reform that covers all Americans, that guarantees affordable, universal coverage and access to care for pregnant women and children, and that provides comporehensive benefits clearly defined by law.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Special Report: Children and Health Insurance
abstract: This report focuses on children who are not covered by employer based health coverage. Statistics from the 1977 and 1987 National Medical Care and Expenditure Survey (NMCES) were used to compile the report.
subject_topic_NAF: National Medical Care Utilization and Expenditure Survey (U.S.)
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: The Impact of Federal Taxes on Poor Families
abstract: This paper explores tax fairness for low income families, shows how much the total tax burden on the poor has risen, how increasing taxes are driving more and more families into poverty, examines existing tax rules that most directly affect low-income families, takes a look at a variety of mechanisms for reducing taxes on low-income families, and reports on major tax reform proposals being discussed in Congress and the media.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: An Opinion Maker's Guide to Children in Election Year 1992
abstract: This report highlights how the USA measures up in world rank in the areas of infant mortality, mortality for children under five years of age, low birthweight babies, proportion of one-year olds fully immunized, number of school-age children per teacher, math achievement of 8th grade students, expenditures on elementary and secondary eduction, teen pregnancy rates, and childhood poverty rates. The spending priorities made by Congress and what the priority agenda for 1992 should look like to ensure that children and families receive the support they need is closely studied.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Key Facts about Child Care and Early Education: A Briefing Book
abstract: This briefing book on child care and early education includes factsheets on a range of child care and early education issues. If includes basic facts about child care and early education, their importance to children, families, abd communities, some of the challenges facing families who need child care and early education, and information on key child care and early education policies and programs. A series of factsheets on the importance of good quality care, the importance of child care to help families work, the inadequacy of the supply of care, and a list of the various programs and policies that help families understand the roles played by federal, state, and local governments as well as private and public sectors. 50-state date, including maternal labor force participation, the number of regulated child care settings, the percent of schools offering extended day programs, selected child care licensing regulations, preschool participation rates of poor children, state rankings on financial commitment to child care and early education, the number of children participating in the Child and Adult Health Food Program (CACFP), and the number of children participating in Head Start are also included.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Key Facts: Essential Information about Child Care, Early Education, and School-Age Care
abstract: This briefing book includes a series of fact sheets concerning child care, early education, and school-age care, as well as information on major child care, early education, and school-age policies and programs. The fact sheets make a compelling case for investing in efforts to help children and families overcome the myriad child care, early education, and school-age challenges they face each day so they can get the quality early learning and after-school experiences they need to succeed.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Children and Federal Health Care Cuts: A National Survey of the Impact of Federal Health Budget Reductions on State Maternal and Child Health Services During 1982
abstract: To determine whether the Reagan Administration's claim that Fiscal Year 1982 budget cuts would reduce only duplicative and wasteful services and not affect the truly needy, CDF initiated a national survey of changes in state maternal and child health services in 49 states (Nebraska did not respond to the Title V portion of CDF's survey) and the District of Columbia to assess the FY 1982 budget cuts' effects on children and families. The survey focused on Medicaid, the Title V Maternal and Child Health Block Grant, and the Community Health Centers Program because they represent the largest sources of federal health funds for mothers and children, are interdependent, and are the health care "providers of last resort" for the poor. The disturbing findings of this survey are included in this report.
subject_topic_LCSH: Federal aid to maternal health services
subject_topic_LCSH2: Federal aid to child health services
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Children and Federal Child Care Cuts: A National Survey of the Impact of Federal Title XX Cuts on State Child Care Systems 1981-1983
abstract: CDF surveyed every state to gather information on each state's nature, quality, and extent of Title XX child care services for this report. Telephone interviews were conducted with state officials responsible for the child care programs funded under the Title XX Social Security Services Block Grant.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: A Fragile Foundation: State Child Care Assistance Policies
abstract: This report is one of a series of reports by CDF concerning child care and early education. It examines state policies concerning important features of each state's child care assistance programs. Topics covered are who is able to receive assistance , how easy it is for them to access assistance, how much parents must contribute towards the cost of care, how much providers who serve children receiving assistance are reimbursed, how providers are paid, and how states administer their programs. Section topics are Income Eligibility Criteria, Availability and Accessibility of Assistance, Maintaining Eligibility, Parent Fees, Reimbursement Rates, Differential Rates, Payment Processes, Contracts and Certificates, Special Populations, and Comparison of 1995 and 2000 Policies.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Decade of Indifference: Maternal and Child Health Trends 1980-1990
abstract: This report assesses the progress made by the US between 1980 and 1990 in reaching maternal and child health objectives set by the US Surgeon General in 1978. The report concludes that the US failed dismally to reach these key goals. As a result, many American babies needlessly died or became disabled. The report states that the health of pregnant women and infants in the US got worse as a result of the failure of seven of eight key indicators.
subject_topic_LCSH3: Federal aid to child health services
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: The Family Support Act: How Can It Help Teen Parents?
abstract: This booklet was created to help teen parent service providers get involved with the Family Support Act (FSA) of 1988, which targeted new education and training efforts to teen parents on welfare. States were required to implement the Act by Oct. 1, 1990. The booklet was designed to assist those who serve teen parents on how to become involved both in planning and providing services.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Vanishing Dreams: The Growing Economic Plight of America's Young Families
notes: Prepared by CDF and Center for Labor Market Studies at Northwestern Univ.
abstract: This report provides a new look at a previous report of the same name published in 1988, which showed that young families with children in 1986 were far worse off economically than the previous generation. New data collected shows that young families with children were barely helped at all by the economic growth of the mid-to late 1980s, and that the tiny gains they achieved during this period were more than wiped out in 1990 by the effects of the Recession.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Vanishing Dreams: The Growing Economic Plight of America's Young Families
notes: Prepared by CDF and Center for Labor Market Studies at Northwestern Univ.
abstract: This report describes the current status of families headed by persons under the age of 30; compares the economic well-being of the current generation of young families in 1986 with that of the preceding generation in 1973; and analyzes the widening gaps between young families with and without children, between young families headed by persons with the least and most education, and between younger and older families.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Families Struggling to Make It in the Workforce: A Post Welfare Report
abstract: This report is based upon survey forms collected from more than 5,000 families and individuals by some 180 local community agencies participating in the CDF Community Monitoring Project (CMP) in 65 cities located in 16 states between January 1999 and December of 1999. The project was designed to take a closer look at families that had left welfare since 1996 and sought help from these agencies. Most of the agencies that participated in the study provide homeless shelter, emergency food, and other services targeted to the poorest of the poor, making the study a unique look at families who are struggling the hardest in these communities.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Working Together for Children: Head Start and Child Care Partnerships
abstract: This report was developed during a round table discussion with program directors to discuss issues involved in developing and implementing collaborative partnerships between child care and Head Start. Program directors from 23 child care and Head Start partnerships completed surveys and participated in phone interviews to generate information for this report.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Head Start: Helping Families Move from Welfare to Work
abstract: This report describes some of the ways in which Head Start agencies are helping to set parents on the path to self-sufficiency. It illustrates the variety of initiatives that are underway relative to the hundreds of Head Start agencies. The report highlights the important work all Head Start agencies are doing to support parents as they move from welfare to work.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Healing the Whole Family: A Look at Family Care Programs
abstract: This report describes 50 family care programs around the country surveyed by CDF. CDF examined programs that treat or serve families struggling with substance abuse, homelessness, domestic violence, and teen parenting. Family care programs were defined as those that allow parents and children to live together in supervised living arrangements for an extended period.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Child Care Briefing Book
abstract: This briefing packet was prepared to provide information on a range of key child care issues. It includes basic facts about child care and its importance to children, families, and communities, as well as information on key legislative issues and proposals affecting child care.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Enforcing Child Support: Are States Doing the Job?
abstract: This CDF report looks at state-by-state child support data to examine the impact of a decade of reform efforts. The report compares data reported by the states to the federal government in FY 1993 and FY 1994 and provides charts for each state to measure progress on key indicators of success for children.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: State Child Care Fact Book 1988
abstract: This report contains the findings of CDF's sixth annual survey on child care funding and priorities in the states and documents the urgent need for investment in child care to close the gap between the need for and the supply of safe and affordable child care. The report is divided into five sections: Summary of Findings, Child Care and Welfare Reform: New Opportunities for States, Elements of a Child Care Agenda, 1988 State Child Care Developments, and the Appendixes, which include detailed data about Title XX services, expenditures and reimbursement rates, waiting lists for child care by state, and key child care officials and advocacy centers in each state.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Child Care: The States' Response: A Survey of State Child Care Policies 1983-1984
abstract: CDF surveyed every state in the country in 1983 to gather information on the nature, quality, and extent of child care serv ices being offered under Title XX of the Social Security Act, the Social Services Block Grant. Title XX is the major source of direct federal funding for child care. CDF published the findings in a study entitled Children and Federal Child Care Cuts: A National Survey of the Impact of Federal Title XX Cuts on State Child Care Systemin Sept. 1983. Since that time, we conducted a second study and updated the findings. This report represents the results of that survey and an agenda that must be implemented if we are to meet the needs of our children and families.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Child Poverty Data from 1990 Census
abstract: This report analyzes figures made public by the US Census Bureau. The Census Bureau's definition of "poverty" and the definition of "children" are given in the report. Data is presented by state for 1979 and 1989 including percentage change in rank. City poverty data for African American and Latino youth is also included in the report as well as the top 20 cities with the highest child poverty rates in 1989.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Protecting Our Children: State and Federal Policies for Exempt Child Care Settings
abstract: This report is one in a series of studies by CDF examining state policies in child care and early childhood education. It focuses on state policies for ensuring the health and safety of children enrolled in informal or exempt child care settings who receive federal child care funds.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Promoting Access to Quality Child Care: Critical Steps in Conducting Market Rate Surveys and Establishing Rate Policies
abstract: This report is one in a series of studies by CDF examining state policies and practices in child care and early childhood education. It focuses on conducting child care market rate surveys and establishing reimbursement policies that can support quality child care. The "Market Rates" concept is explained as well as the "Market Driven" approach to the purchase of publicly funded child care services as included in federal initiatives.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: The Health of America's Children: Maternal and Child Health Data Book
notes: Adolescent Pregnancy Prevention Prenatal Care Program and CDF
abstract: This report traces prenatal care utilization and other key maternal and child health indicators over time and assesses the nation's failure to ensure adequate care to its most vulnerable citizens. The book examines national, state, and large city infant mortality rates; compares U.S. infant mortality rates with those of other coutries; and assesses American children's and pregnant women's access to health care, patterns of childbearing among teenagers and unmarried women, private insurance coverage for children and pregnant women, and the surgeon general's 1990 Objectives on seven key health indicators.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: The Health of America's Southern Children: Maternal and Child Health Data Book - Special Edition
abstract: This report documents the progress made and the progress urgently needed now to improve maternal and child health care in the southern states, to save southern infants' and children's lives and health, and to save taxpayer dollars through preventive health care and improved family support. The report brings together a great wealth of information about maternal and child health programs, as well as key health status and health care utilization stats. Key facts on such topics as infant mortality, low birthweight, prenatal care, and childhood mortality are covered, and the presentation of state-by-state fact sheets help provide a summary of health and program statistics.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Managed Care and Children's Health: An Analysis of Early and Periodic Screening, Diagnosis, and Treatment Services under State Medicaid Managed Care Contracts
notes: Collaboration between National Health Law Program, George Washington Univ., and Center for Health Policy Research
abstract: This report examines the intent to which state Medicaid agencies incorporate the various requirements of the EPSDT (Early and Periodic Screening, Diagnosis, and Treatment) Program into contracts with managed care plans. These contracts are the principle document signifying the plans' service obligations. Because EPSDT encompasses such a broad range of services, this report helps make clear which coverage, service, or administrative requirements remain the responsibility of the state agency and out-of-plan providers and which become the duty of managed care plans.
subject_topic_NAF: Early and Periodic Screening, Diagnosis, and Treatment Program (U.S.)
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Child Care Tradeoffs: States Make Painful Choices
abstract: This report contains data that was collected from comprehensive surveys of all 50 states and DC both in 1991 and in the spring/summer of 1993 to collect key data on the states' AFDC (Aid to Families and Dependent Children) child care policies and programs.
subject_topic_LCSH3: Aid to families with dependent children programs
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Summary of the New Welfare Legislation (Public Law 104-193)
abstract: This report is a summary of the New Welfare Legislation {P.L. 104-193, the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996}, which was passed by Congress and signed into law by President Bill Clinton on Aug. 22, 1996. This new law slashed help for children and families in a broad range of safety net programs. Cuts in federal funds for these programs totaled $54 billion over six years. The New Federal Welfare Law limited welfare to a maximum of five years, restricted food stamp distribution, cut assistance to as many as 300,000 children with disabilities, made it possible to track parents who owed child support payments, and outlined what health benefits children and families could receive.
subject_topic_NAF: United States. Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: The Nation's Investment in Children: An Analysis of the President's FY 1992 Budget Proposals
abstract: This report contains detailed information about the Bush Administration's FY 1992 Budget that affected 12.6 million poor children in our country. Infant mortality rates, homeless children and families, the foster care system, and failing schools are some of the areas covered in the report. Charts and graphs are used throughout the report to highlight the inadequate budget allocations that resulted in little to no improvement to the condition of poor children and families in the US.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: What You Need to Know and Do to Truly Leave No Child Behind
abstract: This action guide describes how the Bush budget brings good news to the rich, bad news to the poor, defies the prophets and the gospels, and mocks American values of fair play and opportunity. It analyzes the Bush administration's budget war on children and steps you can take to protect and invest rather than hurt children. Part I outlines our investment choices as a nation. Part II outlines the key provisions of the comprehensive Dodd-Miller Act to Leave No Child Behind (which the CDF Action Council supports), important victories to date, and how it differs from the Bush administration's No Child Left Behind Act. Part III describes the gap between the Bush administration's compassionate words and uncompassionate deeds for children. Part IV provides state-by-state tables on child poverty, child health coverage, and state spending per public school pupil and per priosoner. The Appendix lists a few resources to help you and key action dates.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: A Call for Action to Make Our Nation Safe for Children: A Briefing Book on the Status of American Children in 1988
abstract: This briefing book is designed for all those in public life, child advocates, community activists, professionals, policy makers, parents, citizens, members of the media, and political leaders of all parties seeking office in 1988 and their staffs. Its purpose is to ensure basic social literacy among the media, citizens, and candidates for public office about the facts and needed remedies for American children and families and about the high economic and social costs of child neglect to every American. Part 1 lays out key facts in important areas affecting children and families, the gap in current successful programs for children and families, and the cost-effectiveness of preventive investment. Part 2 includes key charts on the status of families and children with state-by-state date. Part 3 shows how America compares to other nations in protecting its children. The appendix outlines the history of important federal investments in children and youths and summarizes the polls that indicate that helping children in 1988 is not only a moral and practical imperative but is also good politics.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Your Family's Rights under the New Fair Housing Law
abstract: This booklet introduces the reader to the Fair Housing Amendment Act of 1988, passed by Congress making it unlawful to discriminate against families with children and people with disabilities. The law was a strong response to reports across the country that families with children are very often victims of housing discfrimination. The booklet introduces the reader to the new law and helps the reader determine if he or she has been unfairly denied housing because of their children.
subject_topic_NAF: United States. Fair Housing Amendments Act of 1988
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: A Nation and Century Defining Time: Where Is America Going? How You Can Make a Difference: An Action Guide
abstract: This guide seeks to inform the public about the needs of children and families and how the budget and tax choices and policies in our nation affect them. Included are personal stories of millions of children and families and the choices we have as a people to build a more just nation and world. The CDF Action Council's longer term policy vision incorporated in the comprehensive Dodd-Miller Act to Leave No Child Behindis shared. State-buy-state tables on child poverty, child health coverge, state spending per public school pupil and per prisoner are also included.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Mounting a Prenatal Care Campaign in Your Community
abstract: This report analyzes the prenatal care services needs in communities and compares those needs with services available. The report emphasies the importance of prenatal health care for mothers and care for newborn babies and how good quality care helps prevent teen pregnancies, decreases low birthweight and the infant mortality rate, and assists in providing a strong basis for families.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: The West: Child Care Challenges
abstract: This report is a regional compilation of several state reports, each of which examines the range of child care challenges facing families in that state. State reports include Alaska, Arizona, California, Colorado, Hawaii, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, Oregon, Utah, Washington, and Wyoming.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: New Partnerships: Education's Stake in the Family Support Act of 1988
notes: A Statement of: American Public Welfare Association, Center for Law and Social Policy, Center for Study of Social Policy, CDF, Council of Chief State School Officers, Institute for Educational Leadership, National Alliance of Business, National Assoc. of State Boards of Educ., and National Governors' Association
abstract: This document highlights the aspects of the Family Support Act (FSA) that are relevantr to both the education and the public welfare communities, describes the opportunities that FSA oiffers for both systems to meet their own and shared goals for populations at risk, and emphasizes the importance and benefits of collaborative among education and the human services in implementing FSA.
subject_topic_NAF: United States. Family Support Act of 1988
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: What It Takes: Structuring Interagency Partnerships to Connect Children and Families with Comprehensive Services
notes: A Joint Publication of the Education and Human Services Consortium: Amer. Public Welfare Assoc., Center for Law and Social Policy, Center for the Study of Social Policy, Child Welfare League of America, CDF, Council of Chief State School Officers, Council of Great City Schools, Educ. Commission of the States, Institute for Educational Leadership, Joining Forces, National Alliance of Business, National Assoc. of Counties, National Assembly of National Voluntary Health and Social Welfare Organizations, National Assoc. of Secondary School Principals, National Assoc. of State Boards of Educ., National Governors' Assoc., National League of Cities, National School Boards Assoc., National Youth Employment Coalition, U.S. Conference of Mayors, Wider Opportunities for Women, and the William T. Grant Foundation Commission on Work, Family, and Citizenship
abstract: This is the second in a series of publications published by the Education and Human Services Consortium, a loose-knit coalition of national organizations concerned with the interagency efforts to connect children and families with comprehensive services. The first publication,New Partnerships: Education's Stake in the Family Support Act of 1988, was aimed at state and local education and human services policy makers, administrators, and practitioners and explored the potential for collaboration among education and welkfare agencies in the implementation of the new law. This monoigraph looks at why local schools, health and welfare agencies, youth services agencies, community-based organizations, and others must join forces on behalf of children and families, and offers guidance based on emerging experience about how they can move forward together. A third publication in this series isThinking Collaboratively: Questiona and Answers to Help Policy Makers Improve Services for Children,published in 1991.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: State Developments in Child Care, Early Education, and School-Age Care 2002
abstract: This report provides highlights and updates regarding state actions on child care, early education, and school-age care issues during 2002. It includes a state-by-state snapshot of comparable state policies.
subject_topic_LCSH2: Federal aid to day care centers
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: A Parent's Guide to Child Support
abstract: A guide to assist parents in obtaining child support payments, resolving paternity issues, and enforcing child support obligations
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Stand up for Children Now!
abstract: A guide aimed at addressing the poverty surrounding children in the United States
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Unshared Sacrifice: The House of Representatives' Shameful Assault on America's Children
abstract: This report details the cuts made by the House of Representatives in 1994 that conbtributed to major decrease in services to poor children and families. $30 billion were stripped from crucial child survival programs like SSI (Supplemental Security Income), AFDC (Aid to Families with Dependent Children), Foster Care and Adoption Assistance, the School Lunch Program, Child Care, Services to Disabled, Abused, and Neglected Children, and Child and Adult Food Program.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Summary of Legislation Affecting Children in 1996
abstract: This memo provides a summary of what Congress did in 1996 that mostly directly affected children. Examples of legislation passed by the 104th Congress are a $54 billion cut in the safety net programs that benefitted the poorest children and families, proposals to wipe out Medicaid, food stamps, school and summer meals, and cuts to the Child and Adult Care Food Program, Foster Care, Adoption Assistance.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: The Welfare Reform Debate: Implications for Child Care
abstract: This paper is intended to help child care advocates think about the many difficult and painful issues that could be raised if a state proposes to revamp its current child care system. The document should be viewed as a work in progress because of the uncertainty about the outcome of federal proposals. The paper reemphasizes CDF's stance on opposing any legislation that would significantly increase the need for child care assistance for welfare families without providing sufficient funding to meet the demand, that would jeopardize child care assistance for poor working families, or that would jeopardize the quality of child care.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Windows of Opportunity: Ohio's Children and the 1998 Election
abstract: This report suggests nearly two dozen steps the next governor of Ohio and the legislature can take for children. Nearly all of the measures use existing funding or tax cuts in recognition of the need to finance increases in school funding.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: The Midwest: Child Care Challenges
abstract: This report is a regional compilation of several state reports, each of which examines the range of child care challenges facing families in the state. States included are Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Michigan, Minnesota, Missouri, Nebraska, North Dakota, Ohio, South Dakota, and Wisconsin.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: The Northeast: Child Care Challenges
abstract: This report is a regional compilation of several state reports, each of which examines the range of child care challenges facing families in that state. States included are Connecticut, Maine, massachusetts, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, and Vermont.
subject_topic_LCSH3: Federal aid to day care centers
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Child Support Reform: A State Checklist for Change
abstract: This report focuses on state and Fedaral efforts to provide agencies who work for children to improve child support enforcement
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Transitional Child Care: State Experiences and Emerging Policies under the Family Support Act
name_author 2: Center for Law and Social Policy
notes: Collaborated with the Center for Law and Social Policy
abstract: CDF and the Center for Law and Social Policy (CLASP) jointly made this publication to provide insight into transitional child care policies and operations and to offer recommendations to policy makers and advocates. Transitional child care (TCC) is a new federal child care program that every state must have implemented by April 1, 1990. Established by the Family Support Act (FSA) of 1988, TCC is designed to help families that lose AFDC for income-related reasons to meet their child care needs for one year after AFDC ends.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: 1995 Nonpartisan Congressional Voting Records
abstract: Included are the nonpartisan Congressional voting records for key budget votes in 1995 for children
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: The Health of America's Children
abstract: This 7th edition of Health of America's Children presents national, international, state, and city statistics on the health of America's children and the adequacy of programs that serve them.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Rate Surveys and Policies: Key Issues for Advocates
abstract: This paper is a companion document to Promoting Access to Quality Child Care: Critical Steps in Conducting Market Rate Surveys and Establishing Rate Policies, which discusses the concept of market rates and the elements involved in coducting an effective market rate survey. This paper discusses the role of providers, CCR&R agencies, community-based organizatiins, and other advocates in responding to market rate surveys and policies.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Child Care and Welfare Reform: More Painful Choices
abstract: This report is one in a series of studies examining state policies and practices in child care and early childhood education. The report compares how welfare legislation passed by the Senate in 1995 s some of the basic principles inherent in states' child care costs and the problems and issues states had with meeting the rising costs of providing quality child care for working parents.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: How Safe? The Status of State Efforts to Protect Children in Child Care
abstract: This report examines the measures states took in 1993 to adequately protect children in child care and updates some of the state licensing practices examined in "Who Knows How Safe," a 1990 report published by CDF.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: The High Cost of Child Care Puts Quality Care Out of Reach for Many Families
abstract: The data in this report were collected from local child care resource and referral agencies (CCR&R) through a survey sent to agencies in each state to identify data on child care costs in an urban area, in a rural area, and/or statewide. Average family income is compared to the cost of child care in each state and in each area, and data collected is compared across the states.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: An Advocate's Guide to the Summer Food Service Program
abstract: This report describes the Summer Food Service Program (SFSP). It is designed to assist communities in making sure that children benefit from SFSP and that local, state, and federal officials do their part to ensure that children don't go hungry during summer months when schools are closed. Steps for obtaining SFSP benefits, who is eligible for the program, promising state programs, and a state-by-state list of officials and administrators in charge of SFSP are included in the report.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Information for Action: An Advocate's Guide to Using Maternal and Child Health Data
abstract: This report is based largely on the experience of a project in San Francisco, CA, between 1987 and 1990. A joint university and health dept. effort improved the capacity of the San Francisco Dept. of Public Health (SFDPH) to monitor key information related to maternal and child health, especially for vulnerable groups. The project produced several reports on the status of perinatal health and children's health and well-being in San Francisco. Thise reports demonstrated the potential of information to help community advocacy groups, service providers, and program planners identify priorities for policy decisions and resource allocation.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: A Manual on Providing Effective Prenatal Care Programs for Teens
notes: Adolescent Pregnancy Prevention Prenatal Care Campaign and CDF
abstract: This manual provides information on CDF's prenatal care outreach and action campaign, which is designed to prevent teen pregnancies. The 3 focus areas of the campaign are to expand overall fundiing for access to prenatal care for adolescent and poor mothers, to educate the communities - teens, parents, community groups, and providers - about the importance of ensuring that young mothers receive care, and to involve a range of community and public decisionmaking in setting and implementing goals. The manual contains charts and graphs on percentage of births to women under the age of 20, percentage of births to women who received late or no prenatal care, and percemtage of low birthweight births
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: The High Price of Poverty for Children of the South
abstract: This report provides an in-depth look and explanation into the child poverty statistics in 1996. Despite the booming economy enjoyed by many, children in the South comprised the greatest number of children without health care than any other US region. A state-by-state list of the southern states by counties with the number of poor children living in each county and that county's poverty rate is also included in the report.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Title XX - Social Services in Your State: A Child Advocate's Handbook for Action
abstract: This document explains the Title XX of the Social Security Act, which became effective on Oct. 1, 1975. Title XX provided money to each state for a broad range of social service programs, such as child daycare, homemaker services, senior citizens programs, services to the handicapped, protective services, and legal services.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Working with State and Local Elected Officials: A Guide for Early Care and Education Advocates
abstract: This report was prepared as part of CDF's ongoing effort to provide skill-building information to child care advocates. It focuses on a critical piece of the advocate's strategy kit - working effectively with elected officials and policy makers. The report also outlines some state laws concerning lobbying and charitable organizations.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: An Advocate's Guide to Lobbying and Political Activity for Nonprofits
notes: Written in collaboration with Lichman, Trister, Singer, & Ross - Washington, D.C.
abstract: This guide describes the legal rules governing two kinds of advocacy that non-profit organizations sometimes undertake - Lobbying and Voter Conducting Voter Education and Participation Activities. The guide spells out what non-profit organizations can and cannot do in these two arenas.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: An Advocate's Guide to the Media
abstract: This guide gives practical direction to advocates for strategic and effective use of the media for advancing the causes of children and families.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Stand for Children: A Parent's Guide to Child Advocacy
abstract: This is a guide for parents on how to be the best advocates for their children. The booklet guides parents on how to speak out and act on behalf of children with tips on how to manage advocacy, a listing of national child advocacy organizations that can be of assistance, a listing of public policy and advocacy offices of religious groups, and state-level child advocacy organizations.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: First Steps, Promising Futures: State Prekindergarten Initiatives in the Early 1990s
abstract: The initiatives included in this report are those state-funded initiatives that provide at least some education-related services to prekindergarten-age children. A state-by-state comprehensive listing provides the funding level each state expended in 1991 to 1992, number of children served, estimated cost per child served, targeting criteria, quality requirements, comprehensive services, parental involvement and support, and meeting the needs of families whose primary language is not English.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Child Care Subsidy Policy: An Introduction
abstract: This guide explains and highlights the core policy choices that shape state child care subsidy programs.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Child Care under the Family Support Act: Early Lessons from the States
abstract: This guide summarizes data collected from all 50 states and the District of Columbia as well as other information on state child care policies under the Family Support Act (FSA).
subject_topic_NAF: United States. Family Support Act of 1988
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Who Cares? State Commitment to Child Care and Early Education
notes: Study supported by Ford Foundation and Travelers Foundation
abstract: This reporrt is one of a series of studies examining state policies and practices in commitment to child care and early education. A fact sheet on each state's commitment to Child Care and Early Education (1994) is included in the report.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: The Health of America's Black Children
abstract: This report presents startling statistics on the health of America's Black Children. Infant mortality, maternal mortality, low birthweight, prenatal care, immunization, AIDS, health insurance, drugs, tobacco, alcohol, and violence are a few of the topics explored as they relate to the Black child. Preventive measures and steps that need to be taken to eliminate the gap found in Black children's health issues are explored.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Helping Parents Work and Children Succeed: A Guide to Child Care and the 1996 Welfare Act
abstract: This report examines the many options that policymakers may consider and presents recommendations for policy choices that address both workforce development and child development. The report also presents information on grants and assists states in providing child care for all families - The New Child Care Development Block Grant, part of the New Welfare Act and the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families Block Grant (TANF), which replaced Aid to Families with Dependent Children (AFDC). Transitional Child Care and At-Risk Child Care are also discussed.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Locked Doors: States Struggling to Meet the Child Care Needs of Low-Income Families
abstract: This report presents the findings from a 50-state survey of state child care administrators, conducted by CDF by phone interview during Dec. 1997 to Jan. of 1998. The data collected from these interviews were verified with each administrator after they were collected. The findings of the report indicate that many families face a series of locked doors. Many are not even eligible for help due to low state eligibility cutoffs for child care assistance. Many who are eligible for assistance cannot get it due to waiting lists or are turned away due to inadequate funds. Enormous gaps still remain in our efforts to help low income families work and take care of their children.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: School-Age Care: Federal Funding Opportunities
abstract: This document outlines the importance of school age care as it relates to the children involved, the maintenance of a stable, productive work force, and family and community foundations. Advice for children's advocates and tips for finding funding sources, such as federal funding opportunities, are highlighted.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Child Care and Development: Key Facts
notes: CDF's Child Care and Development Division
abstract: A report on the need for quality child care and how such care impacts children and families
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Homeless Families: Failed Policies and Young Victims
notes: CDF's Child, Youth, and Family Futures Clearinghouse
abstract: This report explains the causes of homelessness among children; makes clear its cost to children, families and society; proposes an agenda to eradicate homelessness; summarizes many studies about who homeless families are, why they become homeless, and how homelessness hurts children and families; and suggests steps to help communities and policy makers prevent homelessness and address the needs of homeless families
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: The South: Child Care Challenges
abstract: This report is a regional compilation of several state reports, each of which examines the range of child care challenges facing families in the state. The states included inthis report are Alabama, Arkansas, Delaware, Florida, Georgia, Kentucky, Louisiana, Maryland, Mississippi, North Carolina, Oklahoma, South Carolina, Tennessee, Texas, Virginia, and West Virginia.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Child Support Assurance: Making Child Support Work for Children
notes: Funding made possible by The Prudential Foundation and the Merck Family Foundation
abstract: A report on the need for child support assurance to protect children who live in single-family households; child support assurance ensures that these children receive a minimum level of support from their noncustodial parent wih federal government intervention to make up the difference if needed.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Rescuing the American Dream: Halting the Economic Freefall of Today's Young Families with Children
abstract: This report details the deep economic losses among young families with children and warns of troubling consequences from these losses, for young and old Americans alike. The report reveals that even though America is richer today than ever before, it does not ensure that families have adequate wages and income, education, training, health care, child care, and affordable housing. Many graphs are used to illustrate issues such as poverty rates of children by age and employment of family head, median family income by age of family head and presence of children, change in median income by age of family and presence of children, and homeownership rates of families with children by age of household head.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: State Investments in Child Care and Early Childhood Education
abstract: This report is one in a series of studies by the Children's Defense Fund examining state policies and practices in child care and early childhood education. It focuses on state expenditures on programs that help low-income families purchase child care, provide preschool education services to children, or provide child care assistance to special groups of families (such as teen parents, migrant or refugee families, or families whose children are at risk of abuse or neglect). Only those programs where the state had discretion over the funding and policies were included--consequently these data truly reflect the level of state commitment to meeting the needs of families and children for child care assistance.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: The Data Book: The Nation, States, and Cities
abstract: This data book was prepared as part of CDF's broader campaign to prevent adolescent pregnancy and to improve the availability and quality of prenatal care for pregnant tenage girls and for all women. The purpose of the book is to provide all concerned persons with detailed but understandable information about where our largest cities, states, and the nation stand on matters involving the health of pregnant women and infants. Part One presents a wide variety of national statistics about mothers and infants and charts the nation's progress toward improving their health. Part Two contains a detailed series of data tables on state health statistics. Part Three presents vital statistics for the United States in 1982.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)

title: Congressional Workbook - Basic Process and Issue Primer
abstract: The goal of this document is to "arm" children's advocates with the basics to help ignite those who care about investments on behalf of children and to educate those who say they are "for" children. This document includes the basics about the budget and appropriations process, the federal budget surplus, how a bill becomes a law, the basics of key leading children's programs, the Committees and Subcommittees in the House and Senate that work on children's issues, key lists of House and Senate leadership, the Congressional schedule, a legislative glossary, and important Web sites for members of Congress and Federal agencies.
repository: Langston Hughes Library (Children's Defense Fund Haley Farm)
